title: Integration to emigration: Why do migrants leave Germany?
description: Germany promises opportunity and stability — yet many migrants feel overlooked and excluded. As more consider leaving, their stories point not only to policy gaps, but the need for a deeper societal shift.

title: UN criticizes Germany over plans to deport people to Afghanistan
description: Germany’s Interior Minister has said he is open to creating a direct line with the Taliban to enable deportations of Afghans living in Germany. The UN has criticized the plan.

title: Germany updates: 1,000 firefighters tackle wildfires in east
description: Two major wildfires have been burning in the eastern German states of Saxony and Thuringia. Meanwhile, several people were injured when a bus overturned in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. Follow DW for more.

title: Majority of Germans want stricter rules on teenage drinking
description: Almost two thirds of Germans surveyed support a ban on young teenagers drinking. German health ministers also agree.

title: Germany seeks direct talks with Taliban on deportations
description: Signalling a shift in policy, Germany's interior minister has said the need for mediators to negotiate with Afghanistan's rulers is "not a permanent solution."

title: Euro 2025: Germany win but Gwinn injury casts shadow
description: A stunning strike from Jule Brand helped Germany to a winning start at Euro 2025. The 2-0 win over Poland was not as straightforward as many imagined though, and another knee injury to captain Giulia Gwinn is a concern.

title: Will Germany's military spending spree deliver broad economic growth?
description: The German arms industry is thriving thanks to a major state-run investment program. But will the country's wider economy benefit?

title: Felize dances and parties in Berlin's famous Berghain in her wheelchair. How can German clubs practice inclusion?
description: Felize dances and parties in Berghain in her wheelchair. How can clubs practice inclusion aside from having awareness teams and wheelchair ramps?

title: Kanye to headline Slovakia festival despite releasing pro-Hitler song
description: Kanye West, who now goes by the name Ye, is set to perform at a Slovakian festival this July. A petition calls for the rapper to be removed from the lineup.

title: How Donald Trump has profited worldwide from his presidency
description: With Donald Trump's return to the White House, the Trump family's fortune is surging as many question the line between presidential power and private profit.

title: Australia: PM denounces synagogue arson attack
description: A man doused the door of the building in Melbourne and set it alight while 20 worshippers were inside.

title: Turkey arrests 3 mayors in crackdown on opposition
description: A crackdown on Erdogan's rival Republican People's Party continues, as three mayors from southern Turkey are held.

title: Ukraine hits Russian airfield day after mass wave of strikes
description: The Ukrainian military said it hit the Borisoglebsk airfield, home to several Russian military aircraft. Meanwhile, US President Donald Trump has expressed frustration with Vladimir Putin. DW has more.

title: Paris reopens Seine River for public swimming
description: Parisians have begun bathing in the Seine for the first time in over 100 years after a ban was lifted. The French capital has created three swimming zones along the river as part of its Olympic legacy.

title: Indian PM Modi receives top civilian honor in Trinidad and Tobago
description: Narendra Modi received Trinidad and Tobago's top honor during a trip to the Caribbean nation. The Indian prime minister has vowed deeper economic partnership between the two sides.

title: Rising death toll in Texas floods as children remain missing
description: Authorities in the US state confirmed more than 20 children who attended a summer camp were still missing as a result of flash floods along the Guadalupe River.

title: Trump signs 'Big Beautiful Bill' into law
description: The signature policy enacts key parts of Donald Trump's agenda and could cement his second-term legacy.

title: Leaders meet for first-ever EU-Moldova summit
description: Chisinau is keen to use the first-ever EU-Moldova summit to push harder for bloc membership. Meanwhile, leaders face opposition from within over progress for another contender for accession.

title: LGBTQ+ in Turkey: Insisting on life
description: The Turkish government is imposing serious restrictions on people's freedom. LGBTQ+ people are among the worst affected. Their existence is threatened with bans, arrests, and blocked websites. But they're not giving up.

title: Pakistan: Several killed in Karachi building collapse
description: At least seven people have been reported dead Friday after a 5-story building in Karachi's Lyari neighborhood collapsed. Rescuers continue to search for survivors.

title: Ukraine: Discrimination and hope drive LGBTQ+ soldiers
description: Up to 10% of Ukrainian soldiers are thought to be from the LGBTQ+ community. While tolerance is improving, Ukraine still does not guarantee legal equality.

title: Cape Verde celebrates 50 years of independence
description: Since gaining freedom from Portugal on July 5, 1975, Cape Verde is regarded as one of West Africa's most stable nations. Overcoming low literacy and inadequate healthcare are just some of its achievements.

title: Football: Ghana star Partey charged with rape in UK
description: Former Arsenal midfielder Thomas Partey has been charged with five counts of rape in the United Kingdom. The Ghanaian international denies any wrongdoing.

title: Do EU structures enable far-right misuse of public money?
description: A leaked audit accuses far-right parties of improperly spending millions in EU funds. Critics say it's not just a scandal but a symptom of the EU system's deeper problems.

title: 'One event' arms pause troubling for Ukraine
description: The US says its pause on arms shipments is a one-off. But amid the turbulent US-Ukraine relationship, the assurance is little comfort to Volodymyr Zelenskyy or his European supporters.

title: Can BRICS project unity amid global tensions?
description: The influence of BRICS, a global forum championed by China, Russia, and India, is on the rise. Still, even its major members have to negotiate internal conflicts amid challenges posed by the Trump administration.

title: Why is Iran doubling down on its nuclear program?
description: Tehran seems defiant on its nuclear ambitions despite the recent war. The nuclear program, launched with US help during the Shah era, was always a show of strength. Now, it also symbolizes the regime's resilience.

title: Should we panic about interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS?
description: Sometimes "the universe comes to us," writes the European Space Agency. For the third time since 2017, an interstellar object will enter our solar system. What is it and are we prepared?

title: EU and Germany push for a new World Trade Organization
description: Brussels and Berlin have launched a new initiative aimed at bypassing the long-standing paralysis of the World Trade Organization, as caused by the United States. But how viable is such a solution?

title: EU-US trade talks: Crunch time looms with no deal in sight
description: EU and US negotiators are attempting to finalize a deal on tariffs before an impending deadline on July 9. Experts say a no-deal scenario is possible.

title: Euro 2025: Plucky newcomer Wales to battle football's giants
description: Two decades ago, Wales’ women’s team was prevented from playing by their own bosses because money was needed for the Welsh men's games. Now the women are making their tournament debut.

title: Ozzy Osbourne and Black Sabbathput on one last show
description: On July 5, Ozzy Osbourne will reunite with Black Sabbath in his hometown of Birmingham for a farewell concert. Here's a look at the wild life of the "Prince of Darkness," including the time he bit the head off a bat.

title: Ukraine hit by major attack as Trump says Putin won't 'stop'
description: Russia attacked Ukraine with 550 drones and missiles, as US President Donald Trump said he was disappointed by his latest call with Vladimir Putin.

title: Kidjo, Padukone make Hollywood Walk of Fame history
description: Angelique Kidjo and Deepika Padukone are among several international celebrities recognized alongside American stars such as Miley Cyrus and Timothee Chalamet.

title: Russia: Is Moscow losing Azerbaijan as an ally?
description: Relations between Russia and Azerbaijan have cooled following contentious arrests in both countries. Russia may be about to lose even more influence in the Caucasus.

title: Euro's climb vs. dollar signals trouble for EU exporters
description: Donald Trump's tariffs were meant to prop up the dollar, but the opposite happened. With the euro and others strengthening against the US currency, European exporters and US offshorers could soon feel the pinch.

title: Germany sees surge in shoplifting cases
description: A new survey of major German retailers has found a rise in theft, committed by organized gangs or by individuals who find it ever more difficult to make ends meet. But some criminologists doubt the figures.

title: Ukraine updates: Zelenskyy in Denmark to discuss cooperation
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is meeting Danish Prime Minister Mette Fredericksen and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

title: French air traffic controller strike strands thousands
description: Airlines have had to cancel hundreds of flights as airport staff went on strike, leaving tens of thousands of passengers in the lurch as the summer travel season gets under way.

title: Blackpink: The K-pop phenomenon is back on tour
description: They're more than a South Korean girl group: As Blackpink kick off their "Deadline World Tour" on July 5, a look at how Jisoo, Jennie, Rosé and Lisa break records and set global trends.

title: Tour de France 2025: Five things to know
description: The 112th edition of the Tour de France is the first in five years to be held exclusively in France. DW fills you in on what you need to know.

title: Liverpool striker Diogo Jota dies in car crash
description: The 28-year-old Portuguese international died near Zamora, in the northwest of Spain. Jota's brother, Andre Silva, also a professional footballer in Portugal, also perished in the accident.

title: What are urban heat islands?
description: Rising global temperatures pose big challenges for city living and fuel talk of "urban heat islands." What are they and why do they matter?

title: Who were Uralic people? Researchers solve an ancient mystery
description: Genetic research traced the ancestral homeland of Uralic people, whose descendants live in Russia, Hungary, Finland and Estonia. But that's not the full story.

title: What is BRICS and why does it matter?
description: BRICS leaders meet in Brazil this weekend to advance plans to challenge Western dominance. As more nations join the economic bloc, how will BRICS reshape power, trade and influence in a rapidly shifting world?

title: Von der Leyen's European Commission faces no-confidence vote
description: Messages over COVID vaccines have cast a shadow over Ursula von der Leyen's presidency of the European Commission and the Commission's commitment to transparency.

title: Amid severe heat wave, EU pitches flexible 2040 climate goal
description: The EU has unveiled its new climate target, a 90% reduction in emissions by 2040. But not all member states are on board, while a provision to outsource part of the climate efforts abroad has generated controversy.

title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs verdict: A trial on fame, consent and #MeToo
description: The Sean "Diddy" Combs' trial tested the limits of fame, power, consent and of the #MeToo movement in an era of AI misinformation and manosphere backlash.

title: DNA shows ancient Egyptians had surprising foreign roots
description: Scientists have sequenced the oldest known DNA from ancient Egypt. It belonged to a potter who lived 4,500 years ago. This rare genetic snapshot offers new insights into the diverse ancestry of early Egyptians.

title: Euro 2025: How is Germany shaping up?
description: A shock group stage exit at the 2023 World Cup and a number of retirements mean a new look Germany face their first big test at Euro 2025. Germany are the most successful team in Euros history with eight titles.

title: EU proposes 2040 climate target with carbon credit allowance
description: The European Commission proposed setting 2040 as the target for a 90% reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The EU wants to be carbon neutral by 2050.

title: Women's Euro 2025: Zero tolerance for discrimination
description: Organizers of Euro 2025 in Switzerland will be placing a particular emphasis on human rights, drawing on experiences UEFA gained at the 2024 Men's European Championship in Germany.

title: Europe heat wave intensifies as fresh warnings issued
description: Record-setting temperatures have forced school closures across Europe, with Spain and Portugal bearing the brunt of the heat wave. At least four people have died amid the extreme weather.

title: Extreme heat's hidden health and economic toll
description: Heat waves are deadly. As they grow more intense and frequent, their toll is mounting, from overwhelmed hospitals to lost labor hours. But countries can adapt to protect lives and the economy.

title: Germany updates: Merz backs not flying rainbow flag
description: Germany's chancellor supported the move not to fly the rainbow flag on the Reichstag building, saying "the Bundestag is not a circus tent." Meanwhile, Germans try to keep cool amid heatwave conditions.

title: India accuses Prada of cultural appropriation over sandals
description: Traditional Kolhapuri chappals have inspired a new Prada design. The luxury brand only acknowledged this fact after critics accused it of replicating the iconic sandals without recognizing the footwear's cultural roots.

title: Too hot to handle: Is this heat the new normal?
description: Heat waves are becoming ever more extreme in many places around the world. Sweltering hot temperatures are putting a strain on our bodies, disrupting society and crippling our infrastructure. Can the world adapt?

title: Ukraine updates: US halts some missile deliveries to Kyiv
description: The halt of some US weapons shipments represents a blow to Kyiv's efforts to fend off Russia's attacks. Meanwhile, French President Macron and Russia's Putin held talks for the first time in over two-and-a-half years.

title: Airlines in turbulence as flight risks rise amid conflicts
description: A range of global conflicts, from Ukraine to the Middle East, are reshaping global aviation. Airlines not only have to avoid certain airspaces but also be prepared for possible interference in their flight systems.

title: Middle East's cultural treasures vulnerable to conflicts
description: During the Israel-Iran war, the countries traded missile and rocket fire that killed and injured hundreds of civilians and put the region's cultural heritage at risk. How can artifacts and historical sites be protected?

title: Germany updates: Iran's envoy summoned over suspected spy
description: The German Foreign Ministry said it will not tolerate "any threat to Jewish life" in the country. Meanwhile, Germans have been grappling with Europe's first major heat wave this summer. Follow DW for the latest.

title: Heat exhaustion or heat stroke: What to do in an emergency
description: In recent years, the arrival of summer has been accompanied by record high temperatures. Here's how to stay safe.

title: Lost Nazi-era novel becomes bestseller
description: Historian and journalist Sebastian Haffner was 24 when he penned an unpublished romance novel set amid Hitler's ominous rise to power. Almost a century later, it's a literary sensation.

title: Azerbaijan police raid Russia's Sputnik media offices
description: Azerbaijan's police have stormed Sputnik's Baku bureau, detaining staff as ties with Moscow sour. The raid follows the deaths of two Azerbaijanis in a Russian police operation last week.

title: Europe heat wave continues as UN chief warns of 'new normal'
description: Record-breaking heat continues to scorch most of Western Europe. Spain broke its June heat record, and extreme temperatures are expected to move toward Germany by midweek.

title: Greek government in crisis after EU subsidy scandal
description: EU subsidies for growing bananas on Mount Olympus? A scandal concerning illegally obtained EU agricultural subsidies has rocked Greece and led to a number of resignations.

title: No Pride, no Palestine: Bundestag boss claims neutrality
description: Julia Klöckner was seen as a surprise choice for Bundestag president — a role that traditionally requires a calm and neutral presence. But Klöckner is an outspoken woman with a taste for pointed language.

title: Germany slashes development aid to boost defense spending
description: Germany is ramping up defense spending — while cutting funds for development cooperation. Aid organizations warn of the consequences for millions of people in a world beset by wars and crises.

title: 'Tipflation:' The growing pitfalls of proper tipping
description: Unwritten rules for tipping differ across the world. But a lot of these rules are being stretched to include more workers, and they aren't afraid to ask for 25%. What are shoppers, diners and package recipients to do?

title: Germany: Social Democrats urge ban on far-right AfD party
description: The Social Democrats say the first legal steps should be taken to ban the far-right Alternative for Germany party as unconstitutional. Conservative lawmakers are less keen on the idea of banning the AfD.

title: Euro 2025: 5 things to know about the football tournament
description: Sixteen of Europe's premier women's national teams are set to compete for continental supremacy. The tournament kicks off in Switzerland on July 2.

title: How the manosphere is making misogyny mainstream
description: Misogynistic influencers with millions of followers propagate toxic masculinity in what has become known as the manosphere.

title: Turkey's largest opposition party CHP set for showdown
description: The CHP's presidential candidate is in prison, and its chairman under investigation. Now, a court case is looming. Turkey's largest opposition party, the CHP, is facing a litmus test.

title: Germany updates: Angela Merkel critcizes asylum policy
description: German ex-Chancellor Angela Merkel has slammed the rejection of asylum-seekers at the border under the current government. Meanwhile, the debate on banning the far-right AfD has gained momentum.

title: In eastern Germany, youths embrace nationalism, extremism
description: In many parts of eastern Germany, showing Nazi symbols is no longer seen as a provocation. Authorities are warning that more and more young people are becoming radicalized. DW explored the reasons in the city of Dessau.

title: Ukraine updates: Kyiv set to quit anti-land mine treaty
description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has signed off on Ukraine's withdrawal from Ottawa Convention that bans the use of land mines. Meanwhile, Kyiv confirmed the loss of an F-16 fighter jet.

title: Europe swelters as early summer heat breaks records
description: With temperatures in Spain setting new records for June, authorities warn the heat will intensify through midweek in Europe. The tennis tournament Wimbledon is set for its hottest opening day on record.

title: Nearly 20% of cancer drugs defective in 4 African nations
description: Across Africa, cancer medications have been found to be substandard or counterfeit. That means people are being given medicine that may not work, or that could even cause them harm.

title: Germany: Social Democrats pick Bärbel Bas as new co-leader
description: Germany's Social Democratic Party has elected its new leadership, placing Bärbel Bas in office alongside her reelected co-chair Lars Klingbeil.

title: Germany and COVID-19: What went wrong?
description: The German parliament is seeking to assess the political impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Former Health Minister Jens Spahn is under attack over the possible misuse of public funds.

title: Are designer handbags linked to illegal deforestation?
description: Leather from cattle raised in deforested areas and on Indigenous land in the northern Brazilian state of Para is being turned into luxury items in Italy, according to an investigation.

title: German government shows cracks over nuclear energy
description: The economy minister attended a meeting of EU states using nuclear energy, even though Germany shut down its last reactor in 2023. The environment minister was quick to insist Germany will stick to its nuclear phaseout.

title: Who is Lars Klingbeil, Germany's vice chancellor?
description: Vice chancellor, finance minister, co-leader of Germany's oldest party, the center-left Social Democrats (SPD): This week, Lars Klingbeil faces tough questions by his party.

title: China's faltering economy in focus of WEF Tianjin meeting
description: The world's second-largest economy is suffering from weak household consumption, and its auto industry is particularly vulnerable. DW's editor-in-chief reports from the "Summer Davos" in Tianjin.

title: How do renewables contribute to energy security?
description: The Israel-Iran war is the latest in a series of geopolitical crises that have placed fossil fuel access in jeopardy. Is renewable energy a safer bet in times of insecurity?

title: Germany suspends refugees' family reunification
description: Parliament has approved government plans to stop family members of individuals with subsidiary protection status from moving to Germany. The controversial move will affect Syrian families in particular.

title: Why more Germans can't afford life on their wages
description: German politicians are fond of saying, "Work must be worth it." But ever more full-time workers need state benefits, and the new minimum wage hike is seen as disappointing.

title: 'Vogue' editor Anna Wintour: Her iconic and controversial moments
description: As the influential "Vogue" editor steps down after a 37-year reign, here's a look at how she turned the magazine into the world's fashion bible — and why she has many critics.

title: Controversial German-Brazilian nuclear agreement turns 50
description: On June 27, 1975, Germany and Brazil signed a treaty on cooperation in the field of nuclear energy. Despite Germany's nuclear phaseout, it still applies today.

title: Will AI really shrink workforces as Amazon boss says?
description: Andy Jassy is not the first executive to warn about the broader adoption of artificial intelligence and how it will fundamentally reshape the workforce. Are the doomsayers right?

title: Is Donald Trump making Europe great again?
description: The US president's erratic trade policy is unnerving investors in the US, while at the same time opening up opportunities for European businesses to capture their attention. Will they seize the moment?

title: Club World Cup: Football players and fans languish in extreme heat
description: Slow-paced soccer matches, sweltering players and complaints about the heat have been the themes of the Club World Cup. Organizers FIFA say they take reasonable precautions but many see a major safety concern.

title: Why does Germany pay taxes for Russian propaganda?
description: The "Russian House" still stands in the heart of Berlin. Critics say it is used to spread propaganda for Putin's Russia. Meanwhile, Germany pays property taxes for the land.

title: Need for vigilance amid new 'Nimbus' COVID variant
description: A new Omicron subvariant has caused infections and deaths in South and Southeast Asia. Europe may see a spike after population immunity fell over the winter.

title: Germany updates: Berlin to end migrant rescue NGO funding
description: The German Foreign Ministry said it would no longer fund NGOs rescuing migrants in distress at sea. Meanwhile, police launched a nationwide operation targeting people suspected of inciting hate online.

title: German football bosses fined over 2006 World Cup scandal
description: A German court has fined the country's football association over a scandal connected to the hosting of the 2006 World Cup. The trial had been going on for more than a decade.

title: German court lifts ban on far-right Compact magazine
description: Judges ruled in favor of the monthly publication, citing freedom of expression protections. The decision could also have consequences for the ongoing debate on banning Germany's far-right AfD party.

title: Jordan's women aiming to follow men to World Cup
description: Jordan's men have qualified for their first World Cup, providing excitement for the country and inspiration for the women to follow in their footsteps at the 2027 Women's World Cup.

title: 'Miracle' HIV drug lenacapavir approved amid drastic US health budget cuts
description: The US has approved lenacapavir for HIV prevention. However, experts worry that cuts to the health budget will "squander" the drug's chance of reducing infections.

title: Germany captain Giulia Gwinn: Perseverance and positivity
description: Giulia Gwinn has big boots to fill, having taken over from retired captain Alexandra Popp just a few months ago. The new captain told DW that Euro 2025 is about much more than Germany's performance on the pitch.

title: Why Germany's former chancellor has triggered fresh outrage
description: Ex-Chancellor Olaf Scholz is to receive a state-paid office with a staff of eight. Opposition parties say this is too much.

title: Over 20% of Europeans exposed to unhealthy noise pollution
description: More than 100 million people are impacted by transport noise at levels harmful to human health, the environment and economy, says a new EU report.

title: Rheingau Music Festival experiments with classical format
description: The Rheingau Music Festival 2025 continues its classical music focus but intersperses elements of pop, electronic and world music to elevate the senses.

title: Germany updates: Merz condemns Russia, urges Gaza ceasefire
description: Ahead of a NATO summit, German Chancellor Merz focused on Germany's role in the Israel-Iran war and Ukraine during his speech to Bundestag lawmakers and the nation. DW has the latest.

title: NATO summit: Germany's military faces new challenges
description: More money for defense, more troops: At a summit in The Hague, NATO wants to set ambitious goals. What does this mean for Germany's military, the Bundeswehr?

title: Kirsty Coventry becomes IOC's first female president
description: Zimbabwe's Kirsty Coventry was elected as the first woman and the first person from Africa to the post of International Olympic Committee president in March. She has now taken over from Thomas Bach of Germany.

title: Uranium: It's radioactive and it's everywhere
description: More common than gold, uranium is abundant on Earth. But less than 1% of the naturally occurring element is useful for nuclear power.

title: What is the Strait of Hormuz, and could Iran block it?
description: The Strait of Hormuz is considered the world's most important gateway for oil transport. With Iran now threatening to close the waterway, industrialized nations are on edge.

title: How China wields rare earths as a strategic weapon
description: China's grip on rare earths — vital for smartphones, EVs and military tech — has left the US, Europe and India vulnerable. Until global supplies increase, Beijing wields great power over the West's critical industries.

title: Isaiah Hartenstein becomes second German to win NBA title
description: It's been 14 years since the Dallas Mavericks' Dirk Nowitzki became the first German to win an NBA championship. Now Isaiah Hartenstein of the Oklahoma City Thunder has become the second.

title: Indian-German design duo make upcycled art to highlight fashion waste
description: An Indian architect and German fashion designer work as Bouley Gandhi, making recycled artworks that shine a light on throwaway fast fashion.

title: Florian Wirtz joins Liverpool to become Germany's most expensive footballer
description: The most expensive transfer in Bundesliga history is complete. Florian Wirtz is leaving Bayer Leverkusen for English champions Liverpool, the next step in an already remarkable career.

title: Americans more vulgar online than Brits, Aussies — study
description: Linguists analyzed websites and blogs to determine where vulgarity was most common. They found Americans swear more on the internet than other English-speaking groups.

title: How dangerous are invasive insects in Europe?
description: Invasive insects like the tiger mosquito and the Asian hornet are becoming increasingly common across Europe, with devastating consequences for human health, agriculture and the environment.

title: 'Crunch time' for climate action, scientists warn
description: The world is running out of time to rein in human-driven climate change, with top UN scientists warning that key indicators are now in uncharted territory.

title: Coco Gauff calls on social media platforms to tackle abuse
description: After the Women's Tennis Association detailed abuse against nearly 500 female players, French Open champion Coco Gauff says more action needs to be taken against online abusers.

title: Who killed Patrice Lumumba, DR Congo's first prime minister?
description: For Juliana Lumumba, Patrice Lumumba wasn't just an independence leader and politician. He has her father. That's why she continues to call for the truth about Lumumba's assassination 64 years ago.

title: Can Israel's economy withstand multiple conflicts?
description: With Israel fighting on at least two fronts, the country's finances and economy are strained. The government hopes higher taxes can cover some of the bills while its high-tech industry remains a safe investment.

title: Star pianist Alfred Brendel dies at 94
description: Hailed as one of the greatest musicians of the last century, the pianist Alfred Brendel passed away at his home in London at age 94.

title: The 50+1 rule in German football: What you need to know
description: In Germany, the 50+1 rule protects professional football clubs from complete control by investors. This feature has many supporters internationally but also attracts criticism.

title: Major oil companies face first 'climate death' lawsuit
description: Climate-change induced extreme heat killed a woman in Seattle, now her daughter is sueing oil and gas giants including BP and Shell for wrongful death. Can the first "death by climate disaster" claim in the USA succeed?

title: Leo Baeck Institute: 70 years marking German-Jewish heritage
description: Founded after the Holocaust, the Leo Baeck Institute marks 70 years of preserving the heritage of German-speaking Jews.

title: Hohenzollern: Germany's ex-royals strike deal over family riches after almost 100 years
description: After years of legal wrangling, the German state and Hohenzollern family — heirs to the former German imperial dynasty — have reached a settlement over thousands of precious items, including paintings and furniture.

title: Betting ads swamp Brazilian football as addiction spikes
description: Exclusive DW data shows how gambling ads at Brazilian football matches are more prevalent than in any other major league. This has huge financial and mental health implications that lawmakers have been slow to deal with.

title: Appendix cancer rates rise in young people — but why?
description: It is the latest cancer to affect young people more now than in decades. Researchers trying to explain the rise in cases are zoning in on environmental factors.

title: Drought has many faces and many impacts
description: Extreme drought and water shortages are increasingly harming crops, the economy and the lives of people around the world. But drought doesn't have the same impact everywhere. What can we do to alleviate water crises?

title: Bach's music sounds out against war and discrimination
description: From the St. John to St. Matthew Passion, contemporary arrangements of Bach masterpieces at the Leipzig Bach Festival highlight oppression and conflict.

title: Why Israel is hitting Iran's vital energy infrastructure
description: As Israel and Iran attack each other with missiles, Israel is especially targeting key oil and gas facilities. That could have a major impact on Iran's economy.

title: Twin Proba-3 spacecraft create artificial solar eclipse
description: In a precision flying formation, the European Space Agency mission revealed new insights into the sun's mysterious outer atmosphere, or solar corona.

title: Pushy sporting parents: How far is too far?
description: The trial of Norwegian double Olympic champion Jakob Ingebrigtsen's father has ended. Gjert Ingebrigtsen was found innocent of abusing his son but guilty of violence against his daughter. It's not an isolated case.

title: What can governments do to stop extreme heating?
description: Most countries globally have agreed to set their own goals to keep the planet from overheating. The pressure is now on for them to do so.

title: Aviation shake-up: Airbus surges ahead of Boeing
description: Boeing dominated the commercial passenger aircraft market for a long time, but it has lost its title as the world's biggest planemaker to Airbus because it's been making headlines for all the wrong reasons.

title: Spain housing crisis: Locals blame tourists and speculators
description: Short-term rentals are worsening Spain's housing crisis, while investor demand continues to drive up prices. For many locals, the situation is devastating.

title: Milei urges Argentines to bank 'mattress dollars' as proof of trust in recovery
description: Argentina's libertarian President Javier Milei has his sights set on an estimated $271 billion in cash stashed away by his fellow citizens to survive economic hardships.

title: VW in Brazil: A dark history
description: Brazil is one of VW's most critical foreign bases. The company's past in the country is blighted by decades of human rights abuses and exploitation.

title: How the LA protests may boost appetite for authoritarianism
description: Psychological research suggests far-right narratives about social breakdown could lead to more support for US President Trump and authoritarianism, not less.

title: Can lab-made blood make up for global shortages?
description: Many countries lack blood donors. The quest to create an artificial, lab-made blood type that could make up for supply shortages is extremely difficult. But there are some technologies that offer hope.

title: Why do countries want rare earth elements?
description: What do electric vehicles, fighter jets and digital cameras have in common? Rare earth elements. They're wanted everywhere but can only be sourced from a few places.

title: Oil prices soar as Iran-Israel tensions shake global economy
description: Israel's attack on Iran has jolted financial markets, as fears grow of a regional conflict that could disrupt oil supplies. The tensions come at a time of heightened uncertainty, driven by Trump's tariff policies.

title: Germany names squad for Women's Euros
description: There were no major surprises as Germany women's coach Christian Wück nominated his final squad for this summer's Euro 2025 in Switzerland. Germany are looking to go one better than the last tournament.

title: FIFA Club World Cup: What you need to know
description: The Club World Cup is set to kick off in the United States to crown the world's best – with more teams than ever before. But it is far from universally loved.

title: Europe's EV sales rebound, but consumer doubts remain
description: After a slowdown last year, electric vehicle sales in Europe are powering ahead. But adoption is uneven, and lingering consumer doubts over batteries and costs threaten to slow the charge.

title: EU and US continue to grapple with child labor
description: June 12 is World Day Against Child Labor as promoted by the International Labour Organization and UNICEF. Despite some progress, around one in 10 children globally work in ways that are deemed harmful or illegal.

title: Former Germany star Lina Magull opens up about mental health struggles
description: Former Germany player Lina Magull says she has recovered her passion both for football and life — and credits a psychiatric clinic stay with helping her to recover.

title: AI art can't match human creativity, yet — researchers
description: Generative AI models are bad at representing things that require human senses, like smell and touch. Their creativity is 'hollow and shallow,' say experts.

title: World Cup 2026: How much of an impact could host politics have?
description: A year out from a football World Cup across three countries, tensions between the US, Canada and Mexico hang over preparations. From travel bans and trade wars to presidential grandstanding, politics could play a part.

title: What's the state of our oceans?
description: Climate change, plastic pollution and overfishing are taking their toll on oceans, biodiversity and livelihoods. Can the UN's ocean conference underway in France find solutions to help protect them?

title: Why NASA, ESA and others want to return to moon
description: Almost six decades since humans first walked on the moon, space agencies and commercial companies want to use it as a gateway to Mars. But that's not all.

title: Fecal transplants: Study is a 'wake-up call' for the field
description: They are hailed as a promising method to restore gut microbiomes, but a study suggests fecal transplants may bring unintended health risks.

title: What Trump-Musk feud means for tech billionaire's business empire
description: Tesla CEO Elon Musk spent some $300 million on Donald Trump's campaign, gaining unprecedented access to the Republican president's administration. What does their public row mean for Musk's empire?

title: Adapting roads, rails and bridges to extreme heat
description: The highways, railways and bridges that keep economies and communities thriving were not built to withstand rising temperatures. How can we stop them from melting down?

title: Japan's ispace fails second lunar landing mission
description: Japanese startup failed to land its unmanned Resilience craft on the moon. The mission was aborted as it was likely the craft had crashed after losing contact.

title: How hard is fire fighting as temperatures rise?
description: Veteran 'hotshot' firefighter Kelly Ramsey has seen how the changing climate is taking its toll on crews working to keep land and lives safe.

title: How Europe is planning to cope with drought
description: As crucial waterways run low and Europe's farmers worry about their crops, the European Union is trying to come up with a strategy to keep the water flowing.

title: What is the answer to overtourism?
description: Many popular holiday destinations are struggling from the environmental impact of huge visitor numbers. How can the issue be tackled?

title: How does Switzerland predict landslides?
description: Switzerland is a success story in predicting landslides — but more must be done to help the rest of the world prepare for these deadly, unpredictable disasters.

title: What are the real impacts of melting glaciers?
description: Glaciers are the planet's frozen water banks. They sustain water supply, ecosystems and even cultural traditions. But many of these sprawling beds of ice are melting. Why does that matter?

title: German court rejects climate case against energy giant RWE
description: Judges have dismissed a climate case brought by a Peruvian farmer against German energy company RWE seeking damages for endangering his home due to melting glaciers.

title: Is Berlin in a 'club death' spiral?
description: Two iconic Berlin techno clubs recently announced they will close. Rising rents and falling profits are partly to blame, but is the city also losing its nightlife luster?

title: How techno shapes the future
description: Techno is harder, faster and more diverse than ever. But what about the much-heralded unifying power of techno? Is this just a cliché?

title: Drag queen rabbi provokes with human message
description: The documentary "Sabbath Queen" follows Amichai Lau-Lavie, the first openly queer rabbi in a long Orthodox rabbinic lineage, in his identity quest and calls for peace.

title: A voice for democracy: Thomas Mann's lasting literary legacy
description: A Nobel prize laureate, literary exile and conscience of a nation in the wake of Nazi rule, Thomas Mann remains a cultural icon 150 years since his birth.

title: Catherine Duleep Singh: The Nazi-defying Indian royal
description: Openly living in a same-sex relationship in early 20th-century Germany, she later used her privilege, resources and courage to help Jewish families flee Nazism.

title: UEFA European Women's Championships kick off in Switzerland
description: The Women's Euro 2025 is underway, with hosts Switzerland losing 2-1 to Norway in Basel after Iceland and Finland opened the tournament. England, Spain and Germany are among the favorites for the title.

title: 'Crying with the lights off:' The realities of life as a professional tennis player
description: With the Wimbledon tennis championships underway, one ex-player has laid bare the struggles faced by many tennis pros.
